response.answer_text: Guns? Pretty damn common. A gun’s a useful thing to have. I’d bet good money most people had some kind of firearm (derringer, rifle, shotgun…), and if they don’t, they know somebody that does. That doesn’t mean everybody’s walking around with guns, though. Even in places like Tombstone and Dodge, you’ll probably be required to leave your guns with the law before you’re allowed entry - it just tends to lead to less problems that way. You’ll get some kind of chit you can trade in for your guns when you move on. Still, a gun to defend your home or shoot game is handy, just keep it in the house when not in use, hm? Gunslingers? As in people that take up the use of firearms against other people, as a trade? Pretty rare. See, even back then, people realized that getting into gunfights is a good way to get shot, so most people weren’t too keen to seek out more than they had to. There were several people that could be called “gunslingers” of various kinds, but we know their names because they were uncommon.

Guns were very prevalent. They were a necessary tool for many people for hunting food and for protection. ‘gunslingers’ are a movie trope. Certainly there were probably outlaws and law men alike who were accomplished marksmen and who, relatively speaking, might have been able to get their guns out a bit faster than less experienced men. But guns in those days were large, notoriously heavy and unwieldy and even more notoriously hard to shoot accurately without taking time to aim carefully. Barrels of guns weren’t widely rifled until after 1899 which also decreased accuracy and distance. So the ‘quick draw’ and ‘fast guns’ in movies are highly highly unlikely.
